body:
Neovim can in some cases wait for new input and block even if there is a pending redraw. 

The easiest way to reproduce this is to `:set scrolloff=9999` and `set cursorline` when using multigrid. In this case the `win_viewport` message will not be received, since there are still pending updates, which in practice leads to very jerky motion in Neovide, see https://github.com/neovide/neovide/issues/2794. 

The added tests are also testing this case, and all of them fail without modifications here.

The fix is in theory quite simple, just update the screen if `must_redraw` is set to true. But in practice it needs some more tests. `redraw_later` has two different meanings. Once of them is, redraw the screen as soon as possible, in order to scroll for example. The other meaning is to ask for a redraw of the screen after the next key press, to reset some state for example. The second case is blocked by `!need_wait_return && (State & MODE_CMDLINE) == 0)`, which seems to be all that is needed, but that is purely based on tests, so there might be some case missing.

comment_regular_data.body:
> `redraw_later` has two different meanings ...

This would be helpful in the docstring for `redraw_later`. 

Also please include your explanation in the commit message.

I addressed the review comments, but I did not add any comments to `redraw_later`. I think it's better that someone, who actually understands what it does takes care of that.

Better yet, if it was refactored so that no special cases are needed at all. I have no idea how hard that would be though, but it seems like it should be possible to request a redraw after the input is processed rather than before.

I compared the test run to master, and didn't find any new `warning: Screen changes were received after the expected state. This indicates indeterminism` warnings.

After some bake-time, we could put this in 0.10.3 (in case 0.11 gets delayed).
